SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Tunisia: Gunmen Attack Two Tourist Hotels
Terrible news coming in from Tunisia. So soon after the museum attack in Tunis !
Gunmen have attacked tourist hotels in the Tunisian town of Sousse - which is popular with British holidaymakers - killing 27.
British tourists said holidaymakers fled from the beach to take refuge in hotels after guns were fired.
One man said his son saw someone get shot as he raced back to the hotel from the sea.
Photographs seen by Sky News show a man in his 60s or 70s lying in a pool of blood in his swimming shorts.

With all the chaos going on in Libya it must be pretty impossible for Tunisian authorities to prevent attacks like this. No way I'm going to travel anywhere in North Africa for a long time to come, the Arab Spring ruined it all.

But of course safety isn't guaranteed on the other side of the Mediterranean either, ISIS is certainly going to take advantage of the hordes of refugees crossing the Mediterranean. Smuggling a couple of Kalashnikovs and some ammo can't be that difficult for them.

It is never going to stop, Ever. We have to many apologists in the west that make life easy for Terrorism. Bored of debating this crap. Just live as long as you can and try to avoid these sky fairy adoring nutjobs.

The death toll keeps rising. Tragic . RIP .
A gunman disguised as a holidaymaker has killed at least 37 people in an attack on a tourist hotel in a Tunisian town popular with British and Irish people.
Terrified sunbathers ran for their lives as the attacker, dressed in shorts and hiding his Kalashnikov inside an umbrella, opened fire on the beach.
He then entered the Imperial Marhaba hotel through the swimming pool area, shooting people as he went and also threw an explosive, witnesses said.

. We have to many apologists in the west that make life easy for Terrorism
Terrorism is an ever real threat and must be dealt with. So what is you solution?

Dismantle all human rights provisions merely on the basis of suspicion? Arrest, internment without trial, stripping ofmcitizenship, deportation by Ministerial fiat without judicial oversight? Of course you could do all that and you will have handed the terrorists a victory. In the 800th anniversary of Magna Charter that would be ironic.

Existing criminal laws were quite adequate to deal with crimes of a political nature. However the current calls for stronger measures indicates a weakness with dealing with the causes of terrorism. The calls may be popular but don't address the issues. They sound simple: just round up everyone, pull up the draw bridge, treat everyone who is not tenth generation german, french, british , etc as a suspect and an outsider who is not entitled to the presumption of innocence or the protection of law.

By all means arrest and imprison persons engaged in or preparing terrorist acts but let us not surrender what we claim as our superior values in the process. Abandon the fundamental principles of justice (presumption of innocence, knowing your accuser, knowing the evidence and be able to test it in a court of one's peers) and you end up with a state that the terrorists would be perfectly happy with.
Terrorism is an ever real threat and must be dealt with. So what is you solution?

Deporting immigrants with serious criminal history back, increased border guarding in the Mediterranean and sending illegal immigrants back to the coast of Africa / Middle-East would already do wonders. This continent really doesn't even need massive amounts of unskilled labour. Lowering refugee quotas and spending that money on peacekeeping operations would also help, it would result in less poorly integrated refugee communities that breed radicalism.

Then after these steps we should put more money into programs that fight radicalization in European Muslim communities. We should make the life of hate preachers as difficult as possible by deporting them & helping their targets, young people who feel socially marginalized, to find jobs / get an education, learn the language if they haven't already and so on.

The amount of terrorism in Europe is pretty much directly comparable to how well we manage to integrate our Muslim immigrant communities. Exactly. Nations like Iraq, Syria and Libya can function only under rule of a strong authoritarian regime that forces all different ethnic and religious groups to live in peace and keeps the radical Islamists suppressed, anyone who claims that anything even remotely close to western style democracy would be possible in these countries doesn't know what he/she is talking about.

The alternatives for these countries are a secular dictatorship, absolute anarchy, a religious dictatorship (like ISIS) and splitting up these countries to something more natural along the borders of areas inhabited by different ethnic and religious groups.

Whenever the west gives support to anti-dictator / "pro democracy" forces in these countries in practice they are supporting "absolute anarchy" and eventual result, the "religious dictatorship" option.

Would you prefer living in Southern Somalia then? I sure prefer the idea of living in a secular dictatorship that protects my right to life and property over living under anarchy where any group of thugs with big guns can (and probably will) eventually rob and kill me no matter what I do.

North Korea isn't exactly a prime example of a functioning state as it isn't able to even feed all of its citizens sufficiently. However Saddam's Iraq, Gaddafi's Libya and Assad's Syria were rather functioning states, as long as you didn't question the government and its rule you could expect to live a rather safe life with enough food to eat.

At least the international community can always negotiate and put pressure on secular dictators like Assad and others who need to think about their international image and keeping up the legitimacy of their rule. Terrorist groups like ISIS on the other hand are much harder to be dealt with. Human rights and freedom of speech can progress only in a society where some entity has has enough power to effectively enforce laws that protect people's rights.
